Wage gap in Rhode Island
text: R.I. advocates: Coronavirus pandemic shows that women's movement has much work to doNews Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Food Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWSR.I. advocates: Coronavirus pandemic shows that women’s movement has much work to doMadeleine Listmlist@providencejournal.comAs the novel coronavirus swept across nearly every country on the planet, it hit some populations harder than others.In Rhode Island, Latino people make up 46% of the state’s case count. Nationally, Blacks and Latinos are being infected at disproportionately high rates.And one group is overwhelmingly serving on the front lines – women.Experts say women make up the majority of health-care and social workers and are more likely to take on caretaking roles for sick people and children at home.In 2020, 100 years after the adoption of the 19th Amendment, women — and women of color especially — are bearing the brunt of the essential labor during the pandemic, all while earning less than their male counterparts.While women have had many political victories over the last century, including electing a record number of women to Congress in 2018, advocates say great strides must still be taken in the areas of reproductive rights, equal pay, health care and improved maternal health outcomes for Black women, who are more likely to die from pregnancy-related complications than white women.The ratification of the 19th Amendment in practice only secured the right to vote for white women, said Françoise Hamlin, associate professor of history and Africana studies at Brown University.Black women faced many barriers to voting and would not be able to fully exercise their right until the passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, she said.Indigenous women were also left behind because they weren’t considered citizens until Congress enacted the Indian Citizenship Act of 1924, said Loren Spears, executive director of the Tomaquag Museum, an indigenous museum in Exeter. Even so, many indigenous people continued to face discrimination at the polls until the passage of the Voting Rights Act, she said.“The first wave of suffragists, they did not want to include Black women,” said Ellie Brown, development officer for the Women’s Fund of Rhode Island, a research and grant organization focusing on women’s issues. “Women, for them, meant white women.”Divides remain in feminism — for example, the Me Too campaign, which launched a movement around justice for victims of sexual harassment and violence, was founded by a Black woman, Tarana Burke, who is often overshadowed by the Hollywood actors who widely popularized the slogan, Hamlin said.But scholars agree that movements have become much more intersectional.“I think that there is more of a sense of, we’re all in this together,” she said.Feminism doesn’t work if it doesn’t include everyone, Brown said, and the issues that advocates need to expand beyond what are normally considered women’s issues – like access to birth control and parental leave.All the major social issues of our time are also women’s issues, because women are often the most affected by them — particularly women of color, according to Debra Mulligan, a history professor at Roger Williams University.Take the coronavirus pandemic. Nationally, 77% of health-care workers and 78% of social workers are women, according to The New York Times; 52% of all workers labeled essential are women, and women of color are more likely to be doing essential jobs than anyone else.In Rhode Island, 87% of health-care support workers are women, and nearly half of these workers are women of color, according to the Women’s Fund of Rhode Island. Ninety-eight percent of childcare providers are women and 20% of childcare center staff are women of color.In 2017, 70% of Rhode Islanders on the state’s family leave program were women who needed to stay home to care for family members. Of all Rhode Islanders who took family leave to bond with a new baby, 61% were women that year, according to the Women’s Fund of Rhode Island.While women continue to serve in the most essential roles, both at home and in the labor market, pay equity continues to be a focal point for women’s rights advocates.Nationally, white women earn 79 cents on the dollar, compared with their male counterparts, Black women 62 cents, Indigenous women 57 cents and Latina women 54 cents, according to the National Partnership for Women & Families, a Washington D.C.-based women’s policy organization.In Rhode Island, women typically earn 84 cents on every dollar paid to men, according to the National Women’s Law Center, an organization focusing on gender justice. For Black women, it’s 59 cents and for Latina women, 50 cents.Change is going to take an overhaul of the systems in place and a restructuring of power, Hamlin said.In Rhode Island, women make up 38% of the state legislature, while they make up about 29% of legislatures nationwide, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.Advocates said they are encouraged by the selection of Kamala Harris to run for vice president with Democratic candidate Joe Biden — the first woman of color to appear on a major party ticket — but they cautioned that, if elected, Harris serving as vice president alone can’t bring about the needed reforms without a broader cultural shift.“Women might have the right to vote and the right to play college sports and do all these things, but there’s still not that kind of social change,” said Kathleen McIntyre, assistant professor of gender and women’s studies at the University of Rhode Island. “There are still ugly stereotypes and disrespectful patterns happening.”— mlist@providencejournal.com(401) 277-7121On Twitter: @madeleine_listWage gap in Rhode IslandMedian weekly earnings for men and women based on educational attainment, according to the Women’s Fund of Rhode Island.
